title: Income inequality: Gini coefficient
Household survey data type Dropdown: Show data from both income and expenditure surveys
subtitle: The Gini coefficient is a measure of the inequality of the income distribution in a population. Higher values indicate a higher level of inequality.
note: This data relates to disposable income or expenditure per capita (exact definitions vary).
sourceDesc: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform

title: Income or expenditure share of the top 10%
Household survey data type Dropdown: Show data from both income and expenditure surveys
subtitle: This is the income or expenditure of the richest decile (tenth of the population) as a share of total income or expenditure.
note: This data relates to disposable income or expenditure per capita (exact definitions vary).
sourceDesc: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform

title: Income inequality: P90/P10 ratio
Household survey data type Dropdown: Show data from both income and expenditure surveys
subtitle: P90 and P10 are the levels of income or expenditure below which 90% and 10% of the population live, respectively. This variable gives the ratio of the two. It is a measure of inequality that indicates the gap between the richest and poorest tenth of the population.
note: This data relates to disposable income or expenditure per capita (exact definitions vary).
sourceDesc: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform

title: Income inequality: P90/P50 ratio
Household survey data type Dropdown: Show data from both income and expenditure surveys
subtitle: The P90/P50 ratio measures the degree of inequality within the richest half of the population. A ratio of 2 means that someone just falling in the richest tenth of the population has twice the median income or expenditure.
note: This data relates to disposable income or expenditure per capita (exact definitions vary).
sourceDesc: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform

title: Income inequality: P50/P10 ratio
Household survey data type Dropdown: Show data from both income and expenditure surveys
subtitle: The P50/P10 ratio measures the degree of inequality within the poorest half of the population. A ratio of 2 means that the median income or expenditure is two times higher than that of someone just falling in the poorest tenth of the population.
note: This data relates to disposable income or expenditure per capita (exact definitions vary).
sourceDesc: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform

title: Income inequality: Palma ratio
Household survey data type Dropdown: Show data from both income and expenditure surveys
subtitle: The Palma ratio is the share of total income or expenditure of the top 10% divided by the share of the bottom 40%.
note: This data relates to disposable income or expenditure per capita (exact definitions vary).
sourceDesc: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform

title: Relative poverty: Share of people below 40% of the median
Metric Dropdown: Share in relative poverty (< 40% of the median)
Household survey data type Dropdown: Show data from both income and expenditure surveys
subtitle: Relative poverty is measured in terms of a poverty line that rises and falls over time with average incomes – in this case set at 40% of the median income or expenditure.
note: This data is adjusted for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries. It is expressed in international-$ at 2017 prices.
sourceDesc: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform

title: Relative poverty: Share of people below 50% of the median
Metric Dropdown: Share in relative poverty (< 50% of the median)
Household survey data type Dropdown: Show data from both income and expenditure surveys
subtitle: Relative poverty is measured in terms of a poverty line that rises and falls over time with average incomes – in this case set at 50% of the median income or expenditure.
note: This data is adjusted for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries. It is expressed in international-$ at 2017 prices.
sourceDesc: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform

title: Relative poverty: Share of people below 60% of the median
Metric Dropdown: Share in relative poverty (< 60% of the median)
Household survey data type Dropdown: Show data from both income and expenditure surveys
subtitle: Relative poverty is measured in terms of a poverty line that rises and falls over time with average incomes – in this case set at 60% of the median income or expenditure.
note: This data is adjusted for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries. It is expressed in international-$ at 2017 prices.
sourceDesc: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform

title: Income inequality: Mean log deviation
Household survey data type Dropdown: Show data from both income and expenditure surveys
subtitle: The mean log deviation (MLD) is a measure of inequality. An MLD of zero indicates perfect equality and it takes on larger positive values as incomes become more unequal.
note: This data relates to disposable income or expenditure per capita (exact definitions vary).
sourceDesc: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform

title: Income inequality: Polarization index
Household survey data type Dropdown: Show data from both income and expenditure surveys
subtitle: The polarization index, also known as the Wolfson polarization index, measures the extent to which the distribution of income or expenditure is “spread out” and bi-modal. Like the Gini coefficient, the polarization index ranges from 0 (no polarization) to 1 (complete polarization).
note: This data relates to disposable income or expenditure per capita (exact definitions vary).
sourceDesc: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform
